bibl.title: Petitioner v. Defendant. Type of document
bibl.note: Our transcription is based on a digital image of the microfilmed original.

div1.p: IN THE UNITED DISTRICT COURT FOR THE WESTERN DISTRICT OF WASHINGTON, NORTHERN DIVISION.
IN THE MATTER OF THE UNLAWFUL DETENTION OF SEVENTY-THREE HINDOO ALIENS.
SECTION 20.

It is an admitted fact that the aliens are held on warrants of deportation issues by authority of Section 20. It will be noted that Section 2 of the Act states that persons likely to become a public charge are subject to be excluded, but under the admission and authority of the Gonzales case, 192 U.S. 1, and the case of Suekichi, 199 Fed. 750, Section 2 is not to be applied to alien residents, but only alien immigrants.
These aliens are held under authority of the deportation warrants and these warrants give as the only ground for holding and deporting said aliens in that they
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY 430-3 PIONEER BUILDING SEATTLE

were likely to become public charges at the time of their entry, and those warrants have taken the place of the warrants of arrest (see heading at top of warrants) and the authorities hold that these warrants must be substantially correct and must be taken at their face value, and if errors have been made of a substantial nature, that the alien should be released on habeas corpus.

The courts have gone to the extent of holding that where the place where the aliens was to be deported was not stated in the warrant, but that there was a mere statement in said warrant that the alien should be deported to the country from whence he came, that that was insufficient, and the alien should be released on habeas corpus.

Attention is called to the affidavit of the interpreter attached hereto, who was present when about half the number of aliens in this case were examined by the immigration board at Manila, and passed, and this interperter furnishes letters from government officials, showing that he was the official interpreter. He testifies that these men were lawfully admitted at Manila and that they could not have received the certificates attached hereto, which it is an admitted fact in the record that all of the aliens possessed, unless they had first had a certificate signed by the immigration officials in Manila, which were presented to the aliens after a proper examination and an admission at a regular port of entry.

In all the cases that have come before the courts, it has been shown that the alien ran across the border at a place other than a regular port of entry or that the alien testified falsely to be admitted, or that in some surreptitious or clandestine manner the alien unlawfully entered. In this case there is not a word or a line of the testimony to show any unlawful entry, but there is a testimony to show that they went to Manila in a boat operated by one of the regular steamship lines, and the court will take judicial notice of the fact that these big ocean liners do not land their passengers at some hidden shore, but that they are met before landing at the port of Manila by the government officers and not a man is permitted to land until after he is inspected and examined by the immigration and custom officers. They testified they were examined regularly and passed, and described, apparently to the satisfaction of the government agents at Seattle, as they did not question the fact of the examination, that they had received an examination similar to the one received in Seattle, and had been passed as entitled to enter, from six months to three years ago at the port of Manila.

It will be noted by referring to Section 12 that the master or commanding officer of a steamer is required to make a report and to pay $4.00 head tax for every man on board who comes within the requirements, and about midway of that paragraph it is stated that no master of any vessel shall be granted clearance papers
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY 430-2 PIONEER BUILDING SEATTLE

for his vessel until he has deposited such list or lists with the collecter of customs, and further that the collecter of customs with whom such list has been deposited, in accordance with the provisions of this section, shall promptly notify the commissioner general of immigration. This is for the purpose of having alines who are about to land, examined properly by the proper board of immigration officers. After they were examined, as appears in the affidavit attached hereto, of the interperter, they are given the certificate marked "A", which it will be noted is signed by the immigration officals who conducted the examination, and that this certificate of identification, which shows proper admission and examination is then surrendered for the certificate marked "B", which it is an admitted fact, were held and surrendered to the government in every case, and special attention is called to the same interpreter's affidavit, in which he tells of having lost his original certificate which showed his having been admitted, and having to get a duplicate, in order to get the certificate which was held and surrendered to the government by each one of the aliens in this hearing. The government not only has failed to show an unlawful entry, but lawful entry, so far as it was in the power of the aliens to show, has been shown. It is preposterous to suppose that if the alien would send a cable to the immigration officer at Manila that he would look at his said records and tell said alien that his name was on the manifest showing him to

have lawfully arrived at Manila on a certain date, but the government, owning and controlling the records, could have gotten that information without any difficulty. The records are in the possession of the government, and it would tke this Honorable Court, or some other court, in order to secure this information from the government from their official records.

It seems conclusive that by reference to Section 36, page 17 of the immigration pamphlet, where it provides "that all aliens who shall enter the United States except at the seaports thereof, or at such place or places as the Secretary of Labor may from tiem to time designate, shall be adjudged to have entered the country unlawfully and shall be deported as provided by Sections 20 and 21 of this Act," especially inasmuch as the same section provides that the provision shall not effect the power of the commissioner general to regulate the entry and inspection of aliens along the borders of Canada and Mexico. After setting out in this section what the government deems to be an unlawful entry, and the aliens having all testifed and show evidence of an admission at Manila, and an examination, and as there is a total lack of evidence showing any kind of an unlawful entry, and further, inasmuch as the government did not demand a head tax from these aliens on entering Seattle, and as paragraph "E" of subdivision 3, page 22 of the pamphlet states that a head tax is not demanded from aliens who have been lawfully admitted to the United States who
HERBERT W. MEYERS ATTORNEY 430-3 PIONEER BUILDING SEATTLE

later shall go entransit from one part of the United States to another, it seems doubtful to us if the court can find that the government has complied with section 20 of the law, and especially do these aliens not come within the provision of Section 2, as subdivision 4 of rule 14, page 33 of the pamphlet states that a failure to present a certificate shall be deemed presumptive evidence that an examination has not occured unless he shows that his presence in the country is lawful or that the limitation of the statute has expired, and certainly this provision is complied with when the alien has testified under oath that he was lawfully admitted and passed at Manila and resided there after such lawful admission for from six months to several years, in view of the faact that he was duly sworn and could be convicted of perjury for falsely swearing, and in view of the further fact that the courts have held that alien residents have the same protection and have the same status as citizens in these matters, and it will not be denied that the oath of a citizen or an alien resident, as the courts have unanimously decided these men to be, who has testifed definitely and positively of the lawful examination and admission, that that when connected with the fact of the furnishing of a certificate only granted after the surrender of a certificate signed by the immigration official, showing a proper examination, and when connected with the further fact that the interpreter who has testified herein, who is a resident of the city of Seattle, testifies that he was present when more than half
of these men were examined by the immigration board at Manila, it seems preposterous to permit the government to say that these men entered the country unlawfully.

Subdivision 2 of rule 14 page 33, states that a certificate shall be furnished as evidence of regular entry, meaning that if this certificate is not furnished, other evidence should be furnished, which has been in this case, and further, in subdivision 3, the alien producing a certificate shall be admitted without further examination, indicating that the certificate simply did away with the examination altogether and failure to have a certificate meant that the alien would have to go through another grilling and tedious examination.

Attention of the Court is called, however, to the fact that this entire supposed presumption as to the failure to have a certificate is not law, and is simply a ruling of the department, which is in no sense controlling upon the court. As to the only other portion of section 20, which is material herein, and which reads as follows, "such as become public charges from causes existing prior to landing", it is plain to see is entirely different language from that used in Section 2, which provides for a liklehood to become a charge, and that the language in Section 20 is mandatory and means that they must have become charges in order to come within Section 20.

Then when we turn to page 36 of the pamphlet, the 7th line from the bottom, of the fine print, and find that the secretary has ruled as follows, "usual instances in which an alien becomes a public charge are where he
enters a public alms house, or hospital or is sent to jail" that the court will readily see that no evidence has been produced, and that the petition for the writ should be granted, as the courts have held that where no evidence is produced on a material point, that the court must discharge the alien. When the Secretary cited instances when an alien becomes a public charge he certainly meant to say that some happenstance out of the ordinary must have occurred to the alien in order to make him a public charge. Then by referring to page 37 of the pamphlet, subdivision cites "Proof in cases which have become public charges from prior causes, physical or mental" and then the Secretary states what should be found in the case of an alien who has become a public charge as follows, "an explicit statement that the alien is a public charge, where and how, and if in an institution, the date of admission thereto". And further, "wether or not the disabilities described constitute the sole causes why the alien is a public charge", and "wheter the causes which render the alien a public charge, existed prior to landing".

Subdivision 4, page 37 shows that this procedure is the necessary procedure in these warrant hearings under Section 20, as is this case. Then at the bottom of page 38, this language is found, "but as to aliens who have become public charges from causes existing prior to landing, etc." and then further in that same paragraph we find the language, "removal from the institution",
indicating that the Secretary did not believe that the alien had become a public charge unless he was in some institution, either a jail, an alms house, or workhouse, or in some poor farm.
UNLAWFUL ENTRY

By referring to the bottom of page 29, the fine print, this language is found, "any alien who enters the United States, across the Canadian border at any other place than those named in subdivision 1 of this rule as a port of entry is subject to deportation under Section 20, etc", showng again that the government admits that aliens entering at Manila or any other designated port of entry, that this is a sufficient showing that there ws no unlawful entry.
Unlawful entry was an entry at night, avoiding and inspection, in re. Dick, 174 Fed. 674
Unlawful entry was clandestine entry, in re. Prentiss 192 Fed. 467.
Unlawful entry was falsely representing self to be a citizen, in re. Williams, 186, Fed. 476.
An alien who becomes a charge within a year shall be deemed to have came in violation of law, in re. Dick, 174 Fed. 674.
Entering surreptitiously is violation of Sec. 20, in re. Dick 176 Fed. 998.
Falsely represents himself to be a citizen, in re. Williams 186 Fed. 479.
LAWFUL ENTRY SHOWN ALMOST CONCLUSIVELY.

The record will show that in each case the
passport from the British government was handed to the immigration inspector at Seattle and surrendered to the government by the alien, and that the said passport was returned to the said alien, and one of these passports is attached hereto, and it will be noticed that on the back thereof is stamped, "landed at Manila January 9, 1912, Immigration division", and that said stamp bears an American eagle, and was doubtless stamped at the time of this man's examination by the immigration board at Manila. These passports are all in the possession of the aliens, as the government did not desire to keep the same, but the fact that they were presented to the government at Seattle will not be denied by counsel for the government, and it seems with that stamp on the passports, that an unlawful entry at Manila can hardly be consistently urged.

Further, the blue and pink papers which are attached hereto were given to the aliens by the trans- portationcompany and these in each instance, were also presented to the government, and returned to the aliens by the immigration inspector, showing that they took passage on a regular line of a steamships subject to the immigration laws, and did not approach the shores of Manila in a launch or in a row boat for the purpose of making a surreptitious entry.
If there was a clandestine or surreptitious entry in these cases, how was it that the government got $4.00 head tax from each man, which is an admitted fact in the record?

If not once lawfully admitted, then the government
would have excluded or attempted to exclude the aliens under Section 2, as they would then have been subject to that Section, and the government admits a priro lawful admission by endeavoring to take the aliens under Section 20.
The Court will take judicial notice of the fact that the head tax money goes in the immigration fund and is collected at the time of the examination by the immigration board.
RETURN SHOULD BE QUASHED.

The petition sets up the faact that no evidence has ever been introduced showing the aliens to be within Section 20, and as the government in its return has not set up any evidence and as the record does not show that there was any evidence, the return should be quashed.
WARRANTS SHOULD BE QUASHED

As the warrant does not substantially comply with law and particularly with Section 20, and as the warrant does not show a compliance with Section 20, but is drawn up in accordance with the language of Section 2, which is not applicable in this case, Section 20 making it mandatory that the aliens have become charges, whereas the warrant specified that they might likely become, the warrant should be quashed.
GOVERNMENT CASES.

The cases cited by counsel for the government
were cases in which an unlawful and surreptitious entires were made, as was the Yamatayo case. In that case the alien was found to be a pauper at the time and was also found to have surreptitously and unlawfully entered without authority, which is not true in the present case.
CERTIFICATES HELD BY FOUR OF THE ALIENS.

Although all of the seventy-three aliens were admitted and passed and had a certificate issued by the immigration board after examination, still the certificate which may be obtained after an alien has lived for a year or two in Manila, in leaving there for the mainland of the United States, was not asked for or obtained by the majority of the aliens, because they did not know of the law permitting them to obtain the said certificates, and no government informed them of this fact, but four of the men did make application and get these certificate, which they subsequently lost on board the boat. These men were Moola Singh, Ram Singh, Ali Bux and Baggu Khan, the first three of whom testified in their examination that they had these certificates, but lost them. The fourth was not asked the question and on that account could not tell the government inspector of his having held such a certificate.
ALIEN RESIDENTS OF MANILA.

The testimony shows that these men lived in Manila for from varying periods of five or six months to two or three years, and that most of them were employed
either by the city government of Manila or in some official capacity, in some cases on the police force, of that city, and the court will take judicial notice of the fact that in order to get these positions and in order to hold them they would have certainly receive sufficient attention and examination in order for the government immigration officers to have taken them up, had they unlawfully entered, before they had been there a matter of several years.
INCORRECT CONCLUSION REACHED.

In the case of TOM YONG, found in 193 U.S. page 517, there was a reversal of the order of the deportation, and the court said, "It is true that the findings of the commissioner and in the district court in cases of this character should ordinarly be followed in this court, and will only be reconsidered when it is clear that an incorrect conclusion has been reached". "In this state of the record an examination thereof satisfied us that the appellants adduced testimony which established that they were bone fide merchants within the meaning of the law at the time the registration was required of laborers by the act od Congress, and, as the orders of deportation were made on the sole ground that the appellants failed to show that fact, the judgments are reversed and the appellants discharged".
BURDEN ON GOVERNMENT.

In the case of Castro v. Williams, 203 Fed. 155, the court said, "The burden is upon the immigration authorities to show that any alien denied the right to enter does not fall within one of those exception to the
general privilege. Although an alien who has not yet entered may not enjoy constitutional guaranties of citizens, he has rights under the law which must be respected." By interference, this decision shows that an alien who has entered does enjoy constitutional guaranties.
ACT TO BE STRICTLY CONSTRUED.

In the case of U.S. v. Redfern, 186 Fed. 150 the courtstates that the immigration statute should be strictly construed. There are one or two other cases which have decided the same point, but I am unable to give the reference at this time.
In one case the court stated that the statutes were very drastic and should be strictly construed.

If the court will read the first few lines of Section 20, the petitioners believe that he will see at a glance that the aliens do not come within the confines of the section on which the warrants were based.

The government admits that there has been no evidence produced or attempted to be produced, showing any unlawful entry. On the other hand, there has been much evidence produced showing a lawful entry.

The government admits that the men have never become public charges and Section 20 makes it mandatory that before a warrant can issue, they must become public charges, the government's contention being that a likliehood or a possibility or a probability, that in the distant future they might become, is a compliance with Section 20, which we are sure cannot be urged with much
force to this Honorable Court.
BECOME CHARGES.

By referring to the 3rd line in the last paragraph of the fine print at the bottom of page 36, the language is used, "those who have become", and it is evident from this wording that the government in the past has read Section 20 in the same manner as counsel for petitioners has read this language to the court, as those who have already become, and that those who are likely to become. This same wording is found in subdivision 7, the third line thereof on page 38.
EXILE ON PRESUMPTION OF GOVERNMENT CLERK, NOT OF LAW, NEVER.

In this free country of ours, when the law requires that some evidence be produced to send an alien who has presumably properly landed, and who has the rights of a resident of this country, out of the country, that some evidence of a material nature will be required, the presumption of the government clerk, who might possibly be a labor leader, is certainly not going to be sufficient for this Honorable Court.
LAWFUL. ENTRY.

In face of all the facts called to the attention of the court, showing a lawful entry of the aliens at a regular port of entry, Manila, and in view of the further facts, it seems that it would be out of the question to hold that there had not been a lawful entry made, and when not a word of testimony is before the court showing an unlawful entry, which is required by law.

Attached hereto and marked Exhibit 1, will be found a receipt for the head tax, signed by the steamship company, showing a sailing on one of the largest vessels making Manila, and showing a regular passage to Manila, which shows conclusively that an examination must have been held at Manila, as these boats are not permitted to land until the immigration officer has passed said alien. The court will take judicial notice of the fact that the government makes these investigations. On the back of Exhibit 1 is found the immigration requirements as instruction to the alien.

Marked Exhibit 2 will be found receipts from the steamship line for $19.00 which was taken from four of the aliens and others of the party had some of these similar receipts, showing this money to have been collected, as they were likely to be quarantined at Manila, showing again the fact that they were proceeding in a lawful manner on a regular steamship line, and were being subjected to every precaution taken in the event of their rejection.

Exhibit 3 was taken from one of the aliens and similar papers were held by some of the others, in which the United States surgeon general passed the alien at Singapore as being free from disease and it will be noted that the government's stamp is on the document as follows, which appears to be, "landed at Manila, P. I. July 22, 1912, Immigration division".

Exhibit 4 is a surgen general's certification which the record will show was presented to the government
by every alien in the number held at the detention office, this certificate showing that the men were proceeding in a lawful manner. It will be noted on these certificates that the consul general's seal appears.

Two marked Exhibit 5 are certificates of registration at Manila in the office of the British consulate. It is submitted that if these men had unlawfully entered, as was suggested by the government, they certainly would not register in the consulate's office on arrival.

Exhibit 6 shows some of the men to have been disinfected and the official stamps of the vessel and the dates appear thereon. These documents were also presented to the government and surrendered by the government to the aliens.

Exhibit 7 is a document similar to one held by the other men and shows the alien to have been proceeding lawfully. He received this paper from the American consulate, showing him to have been disinfected and entitled to proceed.

Exhibit 8 was presented to the government and surrendered back to the alien and is similar to those held by other aliens and is similar to those held by other aliens and was stamped by the assistant Supt. of Indian immigration at Singapore showing him to have been regularly travelling from Singapore to Manila.

Exhibit 9 was also presented to the government and surrendered by the government back to the alien. In that it will be noted said document is stamped "landed at Manila, P. I, July 22, 1912, Immigration Division", showing clearly a lawful entry.
Exhibit 10 are post office receipts showing money to have been sent by registered mail and documents showing money to have been sent by some of the aliens from Manila to Hong King.
GOVERNMENT'S RECORDS NOT ACCESSIBLE TO ALIENS

It would be impossible for the aliens to get the information from the government officials and access is not given to the aliens. To further prove this point, if proof be necessary, the commissioner of immigration at Seattle, Hon. Ellis Debruler, informed counsel for petitioners on the morning of August 28, 1913, that the Honorable Federal Court sitting in Seattle, and the Circuit Court of Appeals and no other court, could compel the government to furnish its original record, but that the best of the court could do would be to request a copy of the same, this statement being made when counsel for petitioners requested that the original record be furnished to this Honorable Court, as there were pictures, material affidavits, and documents, which were not in the carbon copy of the record furnished to the court.

The following citations are furnished to the court in showing that the decisions of the immigration officer in this case is not final, but that the court should go into the record to find if evidence has been produced, and if the finding is based upon some material evidence, and if the law has been complied with, and if the alien in question comes within the requirements of the section of the Act under which the said aliens were taken into custody.

In view of the failure of the government to produce any evidence and in view of the overwhelming amount of evidence in the record, produced by the aliens, and in view of the facilites at the government's hands to produce the evidence, which should have been furnished, and the inability of the aliens to get access to the government's records, it is urged that the warrants should be quashed, as not in compliance with Section 20 upon which section it is admitted they are based.
Respectfully submitted, Herbert W. Meyers Attorny for petitioners.
